security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill template containing markdown files with domain vocabulary guidelines. No executable code exists. All 19 static findings are false positives caused by the scanner misinterpreting markdown placeholders, code fence syntax, and metadata fields as security patterns.

content.value_statement: Inconsistent terminology creates confusion in codebases. This skill establishes a shared vocabulary and entity relationships for your project domain. Teams can document entities, map relationships, and enforce naming conventions.
actual_capabilities: Documents domain entities with definitions and model locations
Maps entity relationships using standard notation
Enforces consistent terminology across code and documentation
Defines naming conventions and status field values
Validates domain logic against business rules
limitations: Requires manual population of domain glossary
Template needs customization for specific projects
Relationship depth limited to 2 levels by default

use_cases.title: Define Domain Models
use_cases.description: Establish clear entity definitions and relationships for complex business domains before implementation.

use_cases.title: Enforce Naming Consistency
use_cases.description: Ensure all team members use consistent terminology across code, documentation, and discussions.

use_cases.title: Standardize API Schemas
use_cases.description: Maintain consistent field names and status values across REST APIs and database schemas.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Domain Setup
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me define the domain vocabulary for this project including core entities, their relationships, and terminology rules.

prompt_templates.title: Entity Relationships
prompt_templates.prompt: Document the relationships between the main entities in this codebase and identify any missing connections.

prompt_templates.title: Terminology Review
prompt_templates.prompt: Review this codebase for inconsistent terminology and suggest standardization for entity names and status values.

prompt_templates.title: Domain Rules
prompt_templates.prompt: Create validation rules for key business constraints and document them in the domain glossary.

output_examples.input: Define domain vocabulary for a blog platform
output: Core Entities: Author (user who creates posts), Post (published article), Comment (user feedback), Tag (category label)
Relationships: Author 1-* Posts, Post 1-* Comments, Post *-* Tags
Terminology Rules: Use 'Author' not 'Writer', use 'Post' not 'Article', status values: draft, published, archived

output_examples.input: How should we name status fields in our order system?
output: Recommended status values: pending, confirmed, processing, shipped, delivered, cancelled
Use 'status' field name consistently across all order-related entities

best_practices: Populate the glossary early in project development before coding begins
Review and update domain vocabulary when adding new features
Share the domain model with all team members and stakeholders
anti_patterns: Using different terms interchangeably (user, customer, client)
Creating duplicate concepts with different names
Ignoring relationship constraints when implementing features

faq.question: Is this compatible with existing projects?
faq.answer: Yes, you can retrofit domain vocabulary to existing projects by documenting current entities and standardizing terminology.

faq.question: What are the file size limits?
faq.answer: The skill has no hard limits, but keep glossaries focused and maintainable for large domains.

faq.question: How does this integrate with my codebase?
faq.answer: It provides reference documentation aligned with models in src/models/, BAML types, and API schemas.

faq.question: Is my project data safe?
faq.answer: Yes, this is documentation-only with no code execution or data access.

faq.question: What if my domain changes?
faq.answer: Update the SKILL.md file to reflect new entities, relationships, or terminology as your project evolves.

faq.question: How is this different from UML diagrams?
faq.answer: It focuses on vocabulary consistency rather than visual modeling, with practical rules for code implementation.
